content.question: NO CALCULATOR IS ALLOWED FOR THIS QUESTION. Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit. Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point. Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for which <math alttext="f of x"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is a real number. <math alttext="The figure presents a 2 row table with 5 columns of data. The heading for row 1 is “t, in hours,” and the heading for row 2 is “R of t, in gallons per hour.” The data in the table are as follows. Column 1. t is 0. R of t is 16. Column 2. t is one half. R of t is 12. Column 3. t is 1. R of t is 7. Column 4. t is three halves. R of t is 3. Column 5. t is 2. R of t is 0."><mstyle><mrow><mtable columnlines="solid" columnspacing="0.0em" columnwidth="9em 0.05em 3em 3em 3em 3em 3em" equalrows="true" frame="solid" framespacing="0.0em 0.5ex" rowlines="solid" rowspacing="1ex" width="auto"><mtr><mtd><mtable><mtr><mtd><mi>t</mi></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mtext>(hours)</mtext></mtd></mtr></mtable></mtd><mtd><mspace depth="2.5ex" height="4.0ex" width="0.0em"></mspace></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd><mtd><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></mfrac></mtd><mtd><mn>1</mn></mtd><mtd><mfrac><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></mfrac></mtd><mtd><mn>2</mn></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mrow><mtable><mtr><mtd><mi>R</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mtext>(gallons per hour)</mtext></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow></mtd><mtd><mspace depth="1.0ex" height="2.5ex" width="0.0em"></mspace></mtd><mtd><mn>16</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>12</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>7</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>3</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow></mstyle></math> The rate at which oil leaks from a drum is modeled by the twice-differentiable function <math alttext="R"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, where <math alttext="R of t"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is measured in gallons per hour and <math alttext="t"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is measured in hours for <math alttext="0 less than or equal to t, less than or equal to 2"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. Values of <math alttext="R of t"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> are given in the table above for selected values of <math alttext="t"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. (a) Use the data in the table to find an approximation for <math alttext="R prime of three fourths"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></mfrac><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. Show the computations that lead to your answer. Indicate units of measure.

frqParts.text: NO CALCULATOR IS ALLOWED FOR THIS QUESTION. Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit. Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point. Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for which <math alttext="f of x"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is a real number. <math alttext="The figure presents a 2 row table with 5 columns of data. The heading for row 1 is “t, in hours,” and the heading for row 2 is “R of t, in gallons per hour.” The data in the table are as follows. Column 1. t is 0. R of t is 16. Column 2. t is one half. R of t is 12. Column 3. t is 1. R of t is 7. Column 4. t is three halves. R of t is 3. Column 5. t is 2. R of t is 0."><mstyle><mrow><mtable columnlines="solid" columnspacing="0.0em" columnwidth="9em 0.05em 3em 3em 3em 3em 3em" equalrows="true" frame="solid" framespacing="0.0em 0.5ex" rowlines="solid" rowspacing="1ex" width="auto"><mtr><mtd><mtable><mtr><mtd><mi>t</mi></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mtext>(hours)</mtext></mtd></mtr></mtable></mtd><mtd><mspace depth="2.5ex" height="4.0ex" width="0.0em"></mspace></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd><mtd><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></mfrac></mtd><mtd><mn>1</mn></mtd><mtd><mfrac><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></mfrac></mtd><mtd><mn>2</mn></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mrow><mtable><mtr><mtd><mi>R</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mtext>(gallons per hour)</mtext></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow></mtd><mtd><mspace depth="1.0ex" height="2.5ex" width="0.0em"></mspace></mtd><mtd><mn>16</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>12</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>7</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>3</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow></mstyle></math> The rate at which oil leaks from a drum is modeled by the twice-differentiable function <math alttext="R"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, where <math alttext="R of t"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is measured in gallons per hour and <math alttext="t"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is measured in hours for <math alttext="0 less than or equal to t, less than or equal to 2"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. Values of <math alttext="R of t"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> are given in the table above for selected values of <math alttext="t"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. (a) Use the data in the table to find an approximation for <math alttext="R prime of three fourths"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></mfrac><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. Show the computations that lead to your answer. Indicate units of measure.

(b) Use a trapezoidal sum with the four subintervals indicated by the data in the table to approximate <math alttext="the integral from, 0 to 2, of, R of t, d t"><mrow><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mrow><mstyle><mrow><msubsup><mrow><mo>∫</mo></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msubsup><mrow><mi>R</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></mrow></math>. Indicate units of measure.

(c) Use the data in the table to evaluate <math alttext="the integral from, 0 to 1, of, R prime of t, d t"><mrow><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mrow><mstyle><mrow><msubsup><mrow><mo>∫</mo></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msubsup><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></mrow></math>.

(d) The sum <math alttext="the sum, from k equals 1, to n, of, R of, open parenthesis, one half, plus the fraction k over n, close parenthesis, times the fraction 1 over n"><mrow><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mrow><munderover><mrow><mo>∑</mo></mrow><mrow><mi>k</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><mi>n</mi></mrow></munderover><mrow><mi>R</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></mfrac><mo>+</mo><mfrac><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>n</mi></mrow></mfrac><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><mi>n</mi></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></mrow></math> is a right Riemann sum with <math alttext="n"><mstyle><mrow><mi>n</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> subintervals of equal length. The limit of this sum as <math alttext="n"><mstyle><mrow><mi>n</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> goes to infinity can be interpreted as a definite integral. Express the limit as a definite integral.

topic.text: 2.3: Estimating Derivatives of a Function at a Point

skill.text: Skill 2.C: Identify a re-expression of mathematical information presented in a given representation
